From: software-engineer@bestfit.com

Subject: Hiring Algorithm

You asked us how we can hire faster. So we built a hiring algorithm (or a computer program) using machine learning. Basically, we will teach a computer to hire like you, but way faster!

How does that work?

That's great.

First, the algorithm will read through past applicants' CVs and whether they were hired or not. It will then try to learn what makes a candidate good or bad. Basically, the program will try to copy your hiring decision process.!

A machine will think like me??

Works for me

It’s impossible for the program to know good or bad candidates without human input - we first need to give it a lot of data to learn from.

Where do we get the data?

How much is a lot?

I need your help with that: can you send me the CVs of all applicants you’ve evaluated so far? Look for a folder named "cv_all.zip" on your desktop

Status: no attachments

Thanks! Machine learning algorithms get more accurate with more data, so here’s what we’ll do: use big tech companies' data! They have huge applicant records, so we can merge our CVs with theirs and train our model! Choose a company below with similar recruitment values!

  • Google
  • Apple
  • Amazon

Thats it! We can now train the algorithm with your data and put it to use!

HIRING ALGORITHM

From: software-engineer@bestfit.com

Subject: Hiring Algorithm Ready!

Our algorithm has been successfully trained. You no longer need to accept and reject candidates yourself; sit back and enjoy the ride!

Great.

Taking A Step Back

As a recruiter, which of these attributes did you value the most?

Education

Experience

Ambition

Skills

Hiring is subjective, which means it could often invoke biases and stereotypes; something many are aware of. Maybe machines can fix that?

NEXT

Training the Algorithm

When the engineering team contacted you, they asked you for your decisions, in cv_all.zip , because software requires human input. That means if you had biases, the software would, and if you were careless, the outputs would be messy! Your data alone wasn't enough to build a machine learning (ML) algorithm, because ML only works on large amounts of data, so you were asked to choose a larger dataset. The probem is, these historical datasets can have all sorts of inequalities built in.

In this case, it largely consisted of applicants from Bluetown, where more people historically worked in tech. In the real world, this could mean your data reflects a history of injustice, like favoring a certain race, gender, or socio-economic background.

What if you ask your algorithm to disregard looking at these differentiators?

NEXT

Behind the Code

There is no on-off switch to ask automated decision-making programs to do the right thing. In hiring, for example, it's not just that data is categorized by race or gender, but that it also represents the colleges, societies, and organizations certain demographics were allowed to be a part of.

When a program learns from years of data, we need to question the data it is learning from. Just because a decision is presented as 'automated' doesn't mean it is right or objective.

Your startup Bestfit might've failed today, but there's no reason our societies should! Head to our website to learn more. We hope it'll make you discuss and ask questions.
